captions.text:
For this fun bet you'll need about 20 cards.
Turn five of the cards face up and then mix

then in with the face down cards. So you'll
end up with a packet that has five face up

cards in it. Have your friend shuffle the
cards as much as they want and then say that

you can place the cards behind your back,
and within 15 seconds, sort them into 2 groups,

and that each of the groups will have the
same number of face up cards. It sounds impossible

but it is this simple. Now there are one,
two, three, face up cards in this group, and

one, two, three face up cards here. You've
won the bet. The solution is simple. When

you place the cards behind your back simply
count off the top five cards and turn them

over. That way, the packet of cards in your
left hand will the same number of face up

cards as the packet of cards in your right
hand. It's amazing and it will work every

title: An Amazing Bet You Will Always Win

comments.text:
I see many people say it doesn't work in the comments, this means you're 
doing it wrong. This is how it works: you make a choice of how many cards 
you'll be facing up in the beginning when these are behind your back take 
the same number of cards of the top as you chose to have face up. If you 
have chosen for m cards up, then you take m cards if you pull n amount of 
cards facing up then the amount of cards facing down in the pulling hand is 
m-n this is also the amount of face up cards left in the deck because u 
started with m and subtracted n cards. by turning over those pulled cards 
the face up cards go face down and vice versa, making the m-n that were 
face down go face up this gives you 2 hands of m-n face up cards. The cards 
facing down will vary though, but you can do the same bet starting the same 
way(with set amount of cards facing up), but saying to have the same amount 
facing down, the only difference is to switch which hand flips the cards.
( m&n are 2 variables with: m=cards you chose to face up at the start 
&n=cards pulled face up behind your back)﻿

comments.author: Ron Ho

comments.text:
Let the first group has n facing cards (before turning the first 5 cards 
over),then the other group will have 5-n facing cards.
When you turn the first group over, the number of facing cards will be 5-n 
which is equal to the number of the second group!

comments.author: theIpatix

comments.text:
He takes away five cards from the deck. Let's say there are two face up 
cards and two face down cards. There are five face up cards in total. That 
means that there are three face up cards left in the deck: 5 - 2 = 3. Then 
he turns over the five cards in his hand. The cards that used to be face up 
are now face down, and the other way around. That means that he made two 
face up cards face down, and made the rest of the cards face up: 5 - 2 = 3 
(three cards are face up). As you can see, we made the same calculation, 
therefore we are left with the same number of face up cards in our hands. 
This works with every number of face up cards.

Attention! Spoiler!
Spoiler
Spoiler!
Look.
If no card in the top5 is facing up and you turn 5 over, you will have 5 
upside cards and 5 upside cards are left in the rest of the cards, as you 
didn´t take one away with the top5.
If 1 card in the top5 is facing up and you turn 5 over, you will have 4 
upside cards and 4 upside cards are left in the rest of the cards, as you 
took one away with the top5.
Same goes for 2,3,4, and 5 cards in the top cards.
Got it?

comments.text:
so if you count off 5 and there are no face up cards, then all 5 faceup 
cards are in your other hand and by turning your 5 cards over, there are 5 
and 5. If you count off 5 and 1 is in your counting hand, that leaves 4 in 
your right hand, and by turning your counting hand over, you have 4 and 4. 
Etc for 2, 3, 4, and 5.

comments.author: InsanityWing

comments.text:
1 face-up card in the top five flipped = 4 face-up cards in the first pile, 
and the remaining 4 face-up cards that weren't in the top five are in the 
second pile.

2 face-up cards in the top five flipped = 3 face-up cards in the first 
pile, and the remaining 3 face-up cards that weren't in the top five are in 
the second pile.

(Similarly with number 3-5) 

[EDIT]
I think this will work with any number of cards (N) where N is greater than 
or equal to twice the amount of face-up cards (F). So:
N (must be) ≥ 2F
Then you simply count out the number of face-up cards and flip them over. 

[SECOND EDIT]
Okay, actually, this ALWAYS works so long as you know how many face-up 
cards there are.

comments.author: daisydook07

comments.text:
Hi daisydook07. I think it's really unfair for you to make such comments on 
this video without actually thinking about the problem.
This trick is basically a simple mathematical problem, and i can prove it 
works every time.

Let's say there's NO face-up cards in the 5 cards you take out. That means 
there are 5 face-up cards in the OTHER deck. So when you turn the 5 
face-down cards, each deck will have 5 face-up cards. <-- Same number of 
face-up cards.  

This can be applied for all other situations (e.g 1 faceup --> 4 faceup). 

So next time, please think about the problem before you comment.
Have a nice day. :3
